turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: His home would be... Mount Olympus.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Call dispatch.  Double the patrols.  I want that area blanketed.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Before we go in I gotta tell you this isn't going to be pretty.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I know that.  I've seen the photo's.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This ain't no photo.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You never know how you're going to catch a suspect.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Peter's right, Captain.  He's got to be forced into making a mistake.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Well, I think you have to play to his ego.  He thinks he's superior.  The more secure he feels, the more chances he'll take.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What did he mean by Huxley?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe we should back up a minute and take a look at what we do have.  All the girls that have been killed have been killed at night.  They're all the same type.  All moved into their homes within the last three months -- and all of them found their homes through Homesearchers.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I thought that Homesearchers was a dead end?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It can't be a coincidence.  The woman that owns it has a son.  She says he's been on vacation in Montana for the last ten days.  We're trying to locate him.  There's also a cleaning service that comes in once a week.  We're checking that out too.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: He moves around a lot.  Why?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Each of those grids represents almost a square mile.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's a big area to cover.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: As large as castles.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes.  Why not just say a building if he meant any general type of structure?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What time did he get there?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: About a quarter to one.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's right, Kathy.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What are you saying?  That I'm seeing what I want to see?  That I'm protecting a murderer?  What?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We can't rely on your judgement anymore.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: And what if he's wrong.  If you were one hundred percent sure it was Peter you would've arrested him.  If it is someone else then he's going to kill again tonight and you're sitting here ignoring the message.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're going to work on the message.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: This stinks!  You want to know what I think?  I think there have been five murders and you've got shit to go on. You need to blame someone and he's the easiest choice.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The most logical choice.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You don't have a shred of evidence!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Did you see his face?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No.  He was wearing a mask... but I saw the cut on his wrist.  It was Peter.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I can't arrest someone for having a cut on their wrist.  Do you have someone you can stay with tonight?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I've got a room at the institute I use when I stay late.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay.  Why don't you go out there. We'll check in with you later.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: If you can think of anything else give us a call.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You know, I hate to say I told you so, but I warned her.  Coming home at all hours of the night.  A young girl new to the city.  This neighborhood ain't what it used to be.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Excuse me... you said earlier that Mary Albert just moved in.  How long ago was that?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Ten days ago.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Do you know how she found the apartment?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Through a rental agency.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Didn't you tell me that Debi Rutlege had just moved into her place also?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I know you're busy so I'll get right to it.  Did you know her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Only in passing.  To say hello to.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Could you tell me where you were last night?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Here.  I played Gregory Lutz.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I know.  You won two games against him and left the auditorium at eight forty five.  Where did you go after that?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: To my room and then I went for a walk.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is a printout from the hotel computer for all the messages logged to your room.  Here's one at 9:04 pm.  It says:  From Debi.  Please call me at home.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She called to give me my schedule for tomorrow.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's interesting about it is you say you only knew her in passing.  Yet, she says on her message for you to call her at home and she doesn't leave a number. That would imply you already knew the number.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I got it from the tournament directory.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why didn't you tell us you were there earlier?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't know.  I was afraid there'd be hours of questions.  I can't afford to miss a game.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mister Sanderson, this is Doctor Sheppard.  She's a psychologist helping us out.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We've already met.  Haven't we... Doctor.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You want me to go with you?  Maybe I can help.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's alright.  We'll take it from here.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What have you come up with on the riddle?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: "Wee Willie Winkie runs though the street."  We think he might be making a reference to himself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Maybe, but I don't think so.  I think it's just a tease.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Upstairs and downstairs in his night gown -- He could be saying the house he's picked is two stories.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We think he might be making a reference to drugs?  Miss Emma is a street term used by junkies for Morphine.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Could Emma be the name of the girl he's going to kill?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Another one?  What word did he leave?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: "Is".  Did you tell him about the institute?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: As large as castles.  You are still light as air, one hundred men can't move me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's using the map as a chessboard! The sonofabitch is playing chess with me!!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How can he be playing Chess with you? You're not making any moves against him.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Maybe I already have.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I still don't see how he could be playing chess against you.  There's only enough grids on the map to be half a board.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's all he needs.  He's making the moves.  It's an opening.  I just can't remember the name.  Okay, it's a game.  He's starting it, so he moves first.  He's white.  e2-e4.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's a commercial area.  No one lives there.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But he had to dump the body there to make the move.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: As large as castles, you are still light as the air, one hundred men can't move me.  It's posed as a question. What am I?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A building?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A building isn't as light as air. What's large, but as light as air and can't be moved?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's not going to give us direct hints. He's going to skirt around it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He uses castles...plural --  then says "can't move me."  Singular.  Not can't move us.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A shadow.  What's as big a castle?  As light as air , but one hundred men can't move it?  The shadow of the castle.  Are there any buildings that have the name Castle in it that cast a shadow long enough to fall across another building?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Wait a minute.  There's an apartment in that area called the Castle Arms.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's got to be it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where were you last night?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are we going to go through this again?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Answer the question.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I went out.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Jeremy would have never killed himself.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe he just got tired of covering for you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This is insane!  Can't you see what's going on.  The killer wants me out of the way.  He's setting me up.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't you understand what I'm telling you?  That's why he wants me out of the way.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I understand that this is just another one of your games.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Look, I'll do anything you want!  I'll sign anything you want!  Just send a car out to the hotel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Alright, c'mon Peter.  We're moving you to a cell.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I signed the confession.  What about the car?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Did you send the car?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's over, Peter.  Let's stop the games.  I'm not sending a car.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You opened with the English.  Lutz won't use it.  He opened his first game with it.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: He knows you're aware of that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then I'll transpose.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: On a variation, yes -- but it must be a variation that is unique.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I suppose you have something in mind?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's a good play, but risky.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You don't win by playing it safe, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We got a problem?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Our computer went on the fritz again. David came up to fix it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Is it serious?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Peter...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I've got be here for the police when they come.  Then I've got to practise. In case you forgot I'm in the middle of a match right now.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You're always in the middle of a match.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I want to be the best I can.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You have something you want to say?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Just thought you might want to talk.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Whatever's on your mind.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who says something's on my mind.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: What do you see here?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Mate in five.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Exactly... and you did this.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: She went into town with Mrs. Lutz.  Did they get him?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Feel like practicing?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah.  Just let me grab a shower.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Bainbridge Books.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Hi, Sara.  This is Doctor Sheppard.  I was wondering if you could tell me if you have a book on chess called "Principals and Tactics" by Anton Berger.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: I can check and call you back.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Thank you.  I'm at 639-7393.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: We'll call you back.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Bainbridge Books.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Sara, this is Doctor Sheppard.  I called you earlier about a book.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, Doctor Sheppard.  We called you back but you weren't home.  We have the book.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Could you please do me a big favor?  In the first chapter the author mentions his three rules of chess.  Could you look and tell me what they are?

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Of course.  Yes, here it is.  Why, they're all the same?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What are they, please?

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: "Carefully".  "Carefully". "Carefully".

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sorry.  I thought it was empty.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It's alright.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Is this your first time here?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I love this hotel.  I stay here every time I visit my parents.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How come you don't stay with them?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Because I love them, but they drive me crazy.  You know how parents are?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.  I don't.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Are you with the tournament?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Are you one of the players?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I've always wanted to learn how to play chess.  I don't have the patience for it.  When did you start playing?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: When I was very young.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It seems like such a complicated game.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not really.  You see your goal and you go after it.  Anything that gets in the way is an obstacle and must be destroyed.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Sounds very violent.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Chess is a reflection of life.  Life is violent.  The strong win.  The weak perish.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: --but you enjoy being the stronger one? You like the control.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you're asking me if I'm passionate about what I do, the answer is yes. Without passion, nothing moves us. What's your passion?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's a very personal question.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I see.  This is going to be a very polite conversation.  What shall we discuss?  The weather?  Movies?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Are you disappointed that I won't answer you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I had just hoped there would be more substance to the conversation.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I thought opening too quickly was a fatal mistake in chess.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Do you always open quickly?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are we talking about me, or chess?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Each circumstance requires a different tactic.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Well, I hope you remember that tomorrow when you play Krikorian.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Well, I think I've had enough.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Getting too hot in here for you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What are you looking for?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Nothing.  I just came in for a steam.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No you didn't.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: They couldn't break the riddle.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Did you think it was going to be easy? You think he was going to lay it out at your feet?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: We need your help.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I offered my help this morning and Sedman turned me down.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: But you're the key.  The one he wants to play the game with.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I can't right now.  I've got a game.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: She could be dead after the game.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She could be dead now.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What if she isn't?  Where are your priorities?  You have to think between someone's life and a chess game?  The girl he killed last night was only twenty one years old!  He dumped her body behind a warehouse like a sack of garbage!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You sure you don't want to eat something?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I don't think I could.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's going to be a long night.  It could take hours before we know something.  You should try to eat.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You sound like my mother.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It wasn't intentional.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Does what's going on bother you at all? Or are you just wearing your game face?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I think it's interesting.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Another kind of game?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: In a way.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: This isn't a game.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, but it is.  He's killing a person everyday and challenging us to catch him.  That's a game.  It has rules and objectives.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How can you look at it so clinically?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Take your average cop.  They deal with death everyday.  If they let emotions get in the way it would cloud their judgement.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's true -- but the emotion is still there.  They just learn to control it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What about you?  Aren't there times when a young child is telling you a story so sad you just want to cry?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Let's change the subject.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay.  So, tell me about yourself.  Are you married?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm just curious.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I think it's best if we don't ask too many personal questions -- I want to keep things on a professional level.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You mean like in the steam room?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's not fair!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you going to tell me you didn't feel something in there?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You're projecting your own desires and reading more into what happened than what actually did.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Very good.  Spoken like a true psychologist.  When confronted with the prospect of your own reality, hide behind quotations.  What is that Masters and Johnson?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You have to win every point, don't you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I just wanted to know if you're involved with anyone?  Let me ask you something?  Do your colleagues know if you're involved or not?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Because I work with them.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're not?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No -- I'm not involved.  And I plan on keeping it that way.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Relax.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How the hell can I relax after seeing what I just saw.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know it was bad.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How could you?  Unless you were there.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know you didn't

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You know, Andy thinks you're doing this.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Doesn't that scare you?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Because I think he's wrong.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Can you go fifteen minutes without thinking about it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.  But I'm open to distractions.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm sure you are.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You know, you're not the easiest person in the world to get close to.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You always want to talk about me.  What about you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Wasn't I just talking about me?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No.  You were talking about chess.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Alright.  What about me?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I dunno.  Where's Erica mother?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She died in a car accident.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's alright.  It was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It must've been very hard on Erica?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It was.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: And you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Have you noticed that every time we start to talk about something serious you start to play games.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm not playing a game now.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes you are.  You're playing word games.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm just trying to get to know you, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?  By attacking me?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Nobody could attack you.  You set your life up like one of your chessboards. You're impregnable -- but at the same time you've become trapped behind your own defenses.  You're cut off from everyone around you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What are you talking about?  You don't even know me.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Does anyone?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I just don't want to fight with you.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Then show me who you are.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This frightens me -- because I'm starting to feel things I haven't felt in a long time.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You've got to face the things you feel.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I thought you were the woman who didn't want to get involved.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I said I didn't plan on getting involved.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You can turn everything around so easily.  This is not just another game, is it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Call room service.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What do you want on it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Would you settle for pepperoni?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If I have to.  I'm going to take a shower.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Did you call?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: The line was busy.  I'll try again.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: They're not delivering.  I'm going to go pick up the pizza.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I thought you said the line was busy?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I tried again and got through.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then why are you backing up?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Peter, you have to admit--

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: --admit what?  That I was right about you in the steam room?  That you're willing to do anything to find out what you want?  Would you like me to leave so you can search the rest of the room?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Peter...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How could you think that, Kathy?  How could you even consider it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: In a fierce magazine you'll find a hint of my actions to come... Why does he set this line apart?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: For emphasis?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Exactly.  It's the key.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: But what does he mean by a fierce magazine?  Violent?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A fierce magazine... brutal...  An angry magazine... A war magazine... a mercenary magazine...  fierce...  Mad.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where's the note?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's replaying the game I played against him move by move, using these girls as the Chess pieces.  All the girls have been found in their homes except Christie Eastman, who was found in back of a warehouse.  Why?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Because to follow the game he played he had to move to that grid?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Right.  Here!  c-4.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Can I come in?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: The other night -- I said some things that maybe I shouldn't have.  I mean, you haven't known me very long and I can see how you thought what you did.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm not looking for an apology, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I was thinking that... maybe when this is all over we could...

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I want someone I can get close to. I don't know if that's possible with you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You really haven't seen my best side.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Peter...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, listen.  You have no idea of the kind of pressure I'm under right now.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's still no excuse.  You treat everything like a game.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I can't think any more, unless it's about you.  I'll be in the middle of a match and instead of thinking about my next move, I think about how you look when you smile.  Remember how you said that I hide behind my chessboard?  Ever since my wife died I've been...  I've been afraid of getting too close to someone again -- afraid of losing them.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You're wife died.  You can't feel responsible for that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You don't understand.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Then help me to understand.  I want to understand.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's not that easy.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Of course it isn't.  It's always difficult when someone you love dies. But you can't feel responsible because she had a car accident.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But I do.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Because she killed herself!!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This letter.  I've never opened it.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Because I know what it says.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Maybe you're afraid of what it says.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If we could just figure out what the next word is going to be.  He said the game's going to end tonight so there's only going to be one more word.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It could be anything.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's got to be grammatically correct.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How did you know it was "carefully"?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Frank told me.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No he didn't.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're right.  The killer told me.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: He didn't tell you either.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This isn't going to be like the phone book, is it?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You're going to be late for your match.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you going to come tonight?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yeah.  I'll be there later.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You beat him.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I got lucky.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: There's a girl in the hospital who is going to live because of you.  You made a difference.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's over now.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I just wanted you to know in case you thought about it in the future.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do we have a future?

turns.speaker: YURILIVICH
turns.text: Hello, Peter.  You played an interesting game last night.  Even though sacrificing your Queen at b-5 is the game I played against Valsney in '82.  I'm glad it helped you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm sure you are.

turns.speaker: YURILIVICH
turns.text: No, I want you to do good.  That way when I beat you at the end I'll look that much better.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're getting sloppy, Yurilivich. You're nervous?

turns.speaker: YURILIVICH
turns.text: I'm not nervous.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, you should be, because this time I'm going to win.

turns.speaker: YURILIVICH
turns.text: Well, then this time you'll have to stay for the whole match, won't you?

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I'm sorry. I couldn't help it.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: I don't have to go through with it either.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: You don't understand. I'm just so <u>relieved</u>. I was <u>sure</u> you'd turn out to be short and fat and gimpy.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Oh. That.  I know what you mean.  I had nightmares all week.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Last night was the worst. I dreamt you had one leg shorter than the other, and walked like a penguin.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Mine was worse: I dreamt you picked your nose in public.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: That's worse.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: You're really not bad looking. Almost handsome.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Well, you're beautiful.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: You <u>might</u> be handsome. I can't tell through all that grime. Besides, you reek of sweat and horses.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: If you're going to marry a warrior, you'd best get used to it.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I have no intention of getting used to it.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Take off your clothes. I'm going to scrub you down.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: <u>What</u>?

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: We're almost married.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: We're not married <u>yet</u>.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Well, then you can go up to the parapet and I'll hand the buckets up to you.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I don't trust you to wash behind your ears.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Never mind my ears! Go away!

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: There. Now you look like someone I might want to marry.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Maybe you'd better look around for another candidate. I don't think my skin is tough enough to survive a lifetime of you and your brush.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I don't have to look around. I've found the husband I want. You can kiss me now.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Thank you, but I can wait.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: I lied.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: I can't wait either.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Lyssa ... Lyssa ...

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Colwyn.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Have they harmed you?

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: No. They watch me closely, but they haven't harmed me.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Lyssa. Where are they keeping you?

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: In a great fortress in the mountains. Wait. Something's happening.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Lyssa ...

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Colwyn ...

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Where is the Fortress?

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I don't know. It's a maze of tunnels. I can't see out.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: I will find you. I will be with you.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I know it.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: I love you, Lyssa, I love you ...

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Colwyn. Colwyn.  I love you, Colwyn.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: Colwyn ...

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: You must move away from the Center.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: All the passages are guarded.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Will your power outward.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: I don't know how.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: You have the power. <u>Will it</u>.

turns.speaker: COLWYN
turns.text: Take the western passage.

turns.speaker: LYSSA
turns.text: All directions are the same here.
